Minnesotan Meat-Packer Meets ReceptiveNEWUEli
by Jon Stempel
"The corporate people who
are trying to ram concessions
down our throats don't have
any feelings," said Dale Francis, who is on strike from the
Hormel meat-packing plant of
Austin, Minnesota, to the
Representative
Graduate
Organization on Tuesday.
The strike began nine months
ago and has received national
attention because of violence
that has occurred because of
the tenacity of both sides.
Francis said that the company had hired a.lawyer who is
a "well-known union buster"
who once said of the workers,
"You drive them into depression and they'll be crawling
back on their hands and
knees." Francis added, "The
Hormel company has followed
that to a tee."
Among the reasons for the
strike cited by Francis were low
wages in light of Hormel's
record profits, a proposal to
"gut the seniority system," and
worker safety.
Calling Hormel's contract
proposal "ridiculous," Francis
said that Hormel is "the most
profitable meat-packing company in the world, although
they keep coming back saying
they aren't making any
money."
Francis cited a company
report that said, "We need to
cut back the wages for our
workers so that we can create
more profits for ourselves." He
added that although this year is
the seventeen in the last twentyfour that Hormel asked for
concessions, the company's
president gave himself a raise
from $339,000 to $570,000.
Concerning worker promotions, Francis said that Hormel
wants to abandon its seniority
system in favor of a job
classification system. Francis
contended that such a system
allows a company to demote
older workers and then "send
them to the unemployment
line."
He also noted that many
workers suffer severe injuries
while they work but that "the
company just ignores it."
Francis discussed the treatment of the strikers, who at
first numbered about 1,500 and
now number about 950.
"We've been harassed, we've
been tear gassed for civil
disobedience because we were
singing songs of solidarity,
we've been redbaited, and
we've been called terrorists,"
he said.
He noted, however, "We've
been non-violent from the start.
The Hormel company went out
and hired an instigator."
Kathy Emminizer, who coordinates the strikers' efforts for
support in Baltimore, added,
"We don't have a renegade,
egomaniacal leadership and
workers that a bunch of dumb
sheep."
Francis continued that while
the American Federation of
Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations (AFLCIO) had said that the strike is
over and was illegal,'The strike
is legal because we are the
primary labor union in the

debate and the certified
bargaining unit."
He also noted that the United
Food and Commercial Workers
union, of which the striking
Local P-9 is a part, had bribed
the workers to cross the picket
lines.
The union, according to
Francis, sent each striker a $40
check, promising each worker
that amount each week if they
were to return to work. The offer, said Francis, soon increased to $75 a week, all of which
was the union's money, but, he
said, "We wouldn't take it."
Francis, who recently visited
Harvard and Tufts Universities
and encouraged the students at
each to join the strikers'
"Adopt a Family" program,
said that many strikers will be
in Baltimore markets May 17
passing out information about
the strikers' cause.
GRO Chairperson Paul
Genest said tat the GRO did not
have the. money to "adopt a

family" but would donate
$100.
Francis concluded, "It's of
essence that we win. We've lost
a lot of things, but the thing
we're mostly concerned about
is our future, and our kids'
future."
Also at Tuesday's meeting:
*The GRO which had concluded a meeting with the deans
before its regular meeting
began, focused its concern on
the apparent University practice
of giving graduate students
much aid in their first year here
and then progressively reducing
it
Representative Mark Peel
suggested, "The reason they're
frontloading is that Hopkins
can't attract people if they
don't do that."
Genest said, "The policy
does not fit the reality of the
amount of time it takes to
finish a doctorate." He added
that the deans were planning to
retain the ten percent of the tui-

tion fee it charges to postcertified graduate students.
Scott
Representative
Holupka added, "The central
administration believes that
grad students are a money drag
on the University. Living within
its constraints, it knows there's
nothing it can immediately do.
I want to know if there's
anything long-term it can do."
After the discussion, the
GRO formed its own financial
aid committee.
*Peel discussed the progress
of the new Coalition for
Women at Hopkins.
"The Coalition is trying to
establish itself as a legitimate
spokesbody for women's issues
on campus," he said, "but the
deans won't recognize the
Coalition for Women unless it
writes on GRO stationery."
The GRO then decided to
send a letter the Coalition produced in February to George
Fisher, Dean of the School of
Arts and Sciences, in its

original form, and attach a
GRO cover letter expressing the
GRO's support of the
Coalition.
*Vice-Chairperson Patrick
Bond said that the JHU Coalition for a Free South Africa
had not decided how long it
would keep its shanty in the
lower quad.
"The Coalition hasn't met to
decide what will happen," he
said. "It's quite possible that it
will be up beyond the end of
this week." Citing a prodivestment petition with 1,200
signatures, he added,"We feel
we have a great power base."
Bond said that the JHU
Coalition plans to continue its
"teach-outs" and strategy
meetings at 12:30 p.m. and 5:00
p.m. daily. He added that the
JHU Coalition will hold "civil
disobedience training" from
10;00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. tomorrow because "many people
have expressed a desire to defend the shanty."

Attorney Kurt Schmoke Gives
Graduation Speech for Tutees
by Kris Ann Cappelluti

Ganesh Ramachandran

Kurt Sdimoke, Baltimore City State's Attorney, who presided at the graduation ceremonies of the JHU Tutorial Project.

The Johns Hopkins Tutorial
Program held a graduation
ceremony for both its tutors
and tutees. Baltimore City
State's Attorney Kurt Schmoke
gave the address at the April 29
ceremony.
The program began at approximately 5 p.m. in Shriver
Hall. Gretchen van Utt, the
JHU Chaplain, welcomed the
sizable audience and explained
that although the tutorial program has been a program of the
Chaplain's Office for thirty
years, this was the first time a
formal ceremony had taken
place.
Before welcoming Schmoke,
Liz van Amerongen, who has
been directing the program for
three years, looked over the
past year, reflecting on the two
field trips taken, and the first

essay contest, sponsored by
Delta Sigma Theta sorority.
Van Amerongen was herself a
tutor during her student days at
Loyola. Before Schmoke began
speaking, she presented him
with a turorial program T-shirt
as a token of the group's appreciation of his presence.
Citing his son's belief that "a
politician should only be allowed to speak no longer than a
McDonald's commercial,"
Schmoke gave a brief address.
He congratulated the graduates,
and applauded them for giving
up afternoons to study. He told
the assembly he knew the "importance of education and the
high cost of ignorance."
Schmoke told the group that
the common demoninator that
most young criminals seem to
have is a high rate of truancy.
He also congratulated Hopkins
itself saying,"You can be proud

of what you're [the tutors]
doing, and of what Hopkins is
doing."
Schmoke and van Amerongen
then distributed diplomas to the
89 graduates and their tutors.
Attendance awards were also
distributed.
The students then went on to
present a talent show, after
which refreshments were served in the Clipper Room.
The tutorial program, whose
motto is "there are no failures
here", is divided into two
groups. The Monday-Wednesday group, consisting of 43
students, runs out of East
Baltimore. The Tuesday-Thursday group of 46 students works
out of West Baltimore. Hopkins
students devote several afternoons to helping children improve their math and reading
skills.

The Unofficial Tour, an
eleven minute film is the newest
tool for recruiting high school
students for Hopkins. The film,
which will finish with location
shooting on Monday, has been,
according to Jerome Schnydman, dean of admissions, "in
the hoping stage" for four
years.
The overall concept, said
Schnydman, was "to present
the ambiance of the campus
along with a unique sense of
Baltimore and the Inner Harbor." Schnydman justified the
need for a recruitment film for
Hopkins by comparing
Hopkins' need to reseed even
the plushest lawn. He also added that Hopkins was "one of
the last [major universities] to
do a film."
Advance planning, which
began in the fall, secured Mark
Hollander, a recent graduate of
Hopkins, and his Baltimorebased film company, On Line
Productions.
Selection of the principals
was conducted by the filming
company. Schnydman noted
that they experienced "a hard
time getting people on campus"
involved. The cast call was
open although postering was
done on the Homewood campus and an ad was placed in the
News-Letter. Some students
were specially solicited, said
Schnydman, through "every
avenue."
The information in the film
is conveyed through realistic
dialogue among two principal
and one minor speakers. The

film's tour guide is portrayed
by a Baltimore high school student while the role of prospective student was given to a
freelance actor. Schnydman
noted that promotional films
normally hire professional casts
rather than actual students. The
film is directed by Steve Yeager,
also of Baltimore.
Schnydman said that reflecting the diversity of the student
body of Hopkins was "not
possible with three people" in
the principal roles. The only
minority representation is in the
secondary speaking role.
Schnydman stated that there
was "diversity in the extras"
most of which were Hopkins
students.
Scenes shot include Mudd,
Maryland Hall, the snack bar,
a stairwell in Gilman (John
Barth has a walk through part),
both quads, the beach,
Homecoming '86, lacrosse
footage, and the Inner Harbor.
There are no shots of Spring
Fair, but it is mentioned in
dialogue overlooking the lower
quad. Neither the Hutzler
Reading Room nor the Gilman
coffee shop was included.
The film is technically listed
as "high budget" said Kristin
Morrison, a Hopkins senior involved as one of the four student production assistants.
Both a steady cam and a crane
were rented to shoot footage
for the film.
The go-ahead for the film
was given last year said Schnydman when he convinced the
deans that the University
should have a recruitment film.

To the Editor:
At 1:00 a.m., April 6, 1986,
eight men, armed with machine
guns broke into home of
Hellets Sono in the township of
Makotopong, South Africa.
Sono, 73, died in the hail of
bullets. His wife Rosalind, 70,
sustained serious head wounds
and their teenage niece, Maria
Mulueke, was brutally raped.
Their daughter, Olive
Shisana, received an Se.D.
from the J HU School of
Hygiene and Public Health in
1984. As a political exile she
could not return home for her
father's funeral, or care for her
injured mother.

of them was affiliated with the
South African Defense Force.
They were most likely members
of one of the numerous death
squads sponsored by the South
African government.
The attack on the Sono family is but a drop in a bucket of
blood. However, the brutal
murder of Sono has profoundly affected the Hopkins community, and has been especial-

ly disturbing for those of us
who know his daughter personally.
JHU's continued investment
in South Africa perpetuates a
system that rapes and murders
the families of its own students.
It is Shisana's hope that her
friends and colleagues will support her in demanding the complete and immediate divestment
of JHU funds from South
Africa.
Lawrence H. Moulton

"Love is What You Have Left to Betray"
A Perfect Spy
by John LeCarre
Alfred A. Knopf, $18.95. 475
pages.
by Cliff Robinson
In A Perfect Spy, John
LeCarre has brought his
readers a complicated, very
emotional story of betrayal and
searches on several levels.
Moreover, A Perfect Spy tells
of Magnus Pym, senior British
Intelligence operative, who
disappears after the death of his
father. Taking a lifetime of
secrets with him, Pym embarks
on a journey through his own
life's story, trying to find his
true "self"—a part of him that
is genuine, and not just a cover
for one of his numerous
betrayals.
LeCarre's main characters
always seem to be tormented,
and are usually involved in
some kind of search for their
own identity. Like the heroine
in The Little Drummer Girl, or
George Smiley in Smiley's People, the lives of LeCarre's
characters are somehow in-

complete, and they look for
something to fill the gap.
Usually, however, that search is
secondary to the main action of
the novel. In A Perfect Spy,
Magnus Pym's search for
himself is the primary focus of
the plot. The main aspect of the
book, the development of
Magnus Pym's character, is
especially well done. Pym is
revealed as a man with no close
personal involvements, no
discernable loyalty to anyone.
He also has no true character,
no driving focus or goals—he
does not know who he is, and
neither does anyone else. While
this may make him a "perfect
spy," it also makes him a deeply troubled man, one in search
of a mission, a cause, or an
identity.
When we are first introduced
to Magnus, we see a man who
is warm, effusive, well-liked by
everyone he knows and loved
by many. He is able to be many
things to many people, and virtually everyone has a slightly
different impression of him.
Yet while many love Magnus,
no one is truly close to him. His
wife and he seem to have a

beautiful relationship, which
everyone admires, but she
doesn't share his secrets. Nor
do his agents or colleagues in
British Intelligence really
understand him.
This ability to change
"masks" so readily makes him
an ideal spy, but behind Pym's
masks, there is nothing. We
soon realize, as does Magnus,
that his entire being is devoted
to the expression of countless
superficial identities—he cannot find a private self apart
from his facades.
skillfully
LeCarre
demonstrates this as Magnus
writes to his son Tom, telling
him about his life. Almost exclusively, Magnus refers to
himself as Pym, especially
when he is acting in an assumed
identity, even with his family.
The only time he says "I" is if
he speaks of a deeply meaningful, important event, and
then only with great emotion.
The fact that "I" appears so infrequently shows that any part
of him which feels deeply, or
truly cares about anything, is
very small and hidden amid the
masks of faces which make up

his "covers." There is little left
of the true Magnus Pym. As
another agent says to him,
"Magnus, you are the perfect
spy. Now all you need is a
mission."
It is the search for this mission that causes Magnus to
disappear, and begin a journey
through his past. "Sometimes
our actions are questions, not
answers," he says, and calls his
disappearance "The first conscious decision I ever made in
my life." As he unravels the
threads of his life, his
childhood is shown to be a
training ground for a lifetime of
betrayals, hidden meanings and
intrigue. At the same time,
British Intelligence is looking
for him, and trying to understand him and his motives.
Gradually, they both begin to
realize that for his whole life,
his lack of conscious decisions
is a result of his not having a
cause to be loyal to, a single
person to care about, or any
driving force behind his actions. He becomes enmeshed in
a circle of duplicity, with double agents whose loyalty is constantly in question. His rela-

tionship with his wife parallels
his career, and his loyalty to his
country, and again he is unwilling, or unable, to make a strong
commitment.
To a large extent, Pym's
search goes unresolved. Even at
the end of the book, questions
still remain about the ultimate
motives of both Pym and some
of the agents he is involved
with. We are not sure if he intended to betray those things he
thought were important for
some greater cause. He may
love his country, his father, his
son. Or he may still have no
loyalty, not even to himself. It
seems that he himself is unsure,
as if LeCarre wishes to avoid
making any statement about
the final value of commitments.
Instead, we just see that all
Pym's relationships are based
upon deceit. Pym says, "Love
is what you have left to
betray," so it may very well be
that he loves most what he
betrays. It does not matter
ultimately, for when all the interpretations are stripped away,
A Perfect Spy is still an excellent spy novel, and wellrecommended.

To the Editor:
, Lately, the Coalition for a
Free South Africa has indulged
its confrontational streak and
delighted greatly in hurling the
epithet "stooge" in the direction of Mangosuthu Buthelezi,
leader of the Inkatha movement. This not only goes far in
darkening and trivializing the
open debate on campus about
divestment, but is belies many
facts that are crucial to all those
groups who are seeking change

in South Africa by invovling
themselves in this debate.
Mangosuthu Buthelezi, a
devout Anglican, follows a
principle of political action that
should be well-known to all
Americans. This is the tenet of
nonviolent action as a means of
controlled change and freedom
and justice for all peoples. This
is no claim that Buthelezi
created this philosophy; it is
well known that two figures in
world history no less than
Mahatma Gandhi and Martin
Luther King, Jr. were pioneers
in this system of ideals.
However, do we label the firs a
"stooge" of the British colonial
government in India or of
Viceroy Mountbatten? Do we
call King a "pawn" or
"stooge" of John F. Kennedy
simply because he was against
bloodshed? The answer is a
simple "no." Both men are
revered as great heroes and only labeled as villains by those
who do not understand that
violence is idiocy.
The Coalition often asks how
long the peoples of nonviolence
wish to wait to end apartheid.
50 years? 100 years? However,
an equally relevant question is
how many lives do the supporters of murder and guerrilla
warfare wish to take to end
apartheid? 100,000 dead?
300,000 dead? These are not
unrealistic figures if total civil
war erupts in South Africa.
People such as the ANC's
Oliver, Bishop Tutu and the
Coalition for a Free South
Africa (by virtue of their
devoted support of the ANC)
all seem to advocate violence.
As Tambo has said,"We wish
to make this country ungovernable." Buthelezi and Inkatha
can only denounce this violence
and fight off the rain of epithets
of hatred thrown toward them.
In the words of Buthelezi, "I
realize that there are many peo'pie who hate my guts for daring even to grope for a peaceful
solution after the violence that
has been unleashed against
blacks in the past months. I am
not ashamed to do whatever is
within the realm of the possible
to prevent bloodshed." It is for
this reason that Buthelezi is
against divestment and works
to preserve peace and stability
in South Africa, as well as to
end apartheid.
William Wallace
The writer is a member of
Students for Inkatha.

The Sour Beef was tender but
smothered in a large amount of
gravy which was a little too
sweet. The dumplings were
similar in flavor and a bit
bland. The eggplant, however,

was tasty.
The Wiener Schnitzel(breaded veal), was topped with an
egg, sunny side up, anchovies,
and a lemon wedge on the side.
Although this was very good,
the spaetzel and potato salad
were disappointing. The potato
salad had an odd,smokey sweet
flavor, while the spaetzel,
which should have been fried
instead of boiled, was too

The combination Sausage

with horse radish and Grey
Poupon mustard. One tasted a

hot dog. Two were a bit spicier
but still mild. The last was a
turkey sausage and was very
pleasing. The broccoli and
potatoes were good but not
special. We all found the dinner to be filling.

Strawberry Pie and Chocolate
Victory Torte (both $2.75).
The pie, containing nearly

whole berries, and topped with
whipped cream and almonds,
was amazing. The torte was
layers of cake and cream, and
also delicious, but by comparison, the strawberry pie was
outstanding. Both portions
were huge.
We also tried the Peachtree
Schnapps, which was very
flavorful and had a wonderful
aroma; and the Applebarrel,
which was also rich in flavor
and quite nice.
All in all, Haussner's proved
to be a pleasant dining experience. The prices are
reasonable and the portions
generous. The waitress was
friendly and gave us good service. The restaurant is closed on
Sundays and Mondays and
reservations for dinner are not
accepted. The most memorable
parts of the evening were,
without a doubt, the beautiful
artwork and glorious desserts.
If any students should find
themselves in the area, I recommend dining at Haussner's.

The Year in Review: The Ten B
It has been, in many ways, an unusual academic year
for Hopkins. At a school known for having a politically apathetic student body, protests and sit-ins became
almost commonplace. At a school with a relatively
small campus, the administration announced it would
spend more than $200 million to expand in the next
few years alone. At perhaps the nation's leading premed factory, the MCAT (the standard medical school
admissions test) became optional.
In other ways, though, it has been an utterly typical
year. Tuition was increased almost $1000, the Student
Council feuded with the Student Activities Commission and WJHU suffered more delays on the road to
its much-discussed power boost.
As a way of looking back at 1985-86, the Editor and
News Editors of the News-Letter chose the year's 10
biggest news events. All of them effected students,
faculty members and administrators; some of them
changed (or will change) the nature of Hopkins.
First on the list is the continuing controversy
throughout the year about the University's investments
in corporations which do business in South Africa.
Quite Simply, no other story even came close to capturing as much attention as this one. Second are the
plague of bomb threats which struck the Milton S.
Eisenhower Library this spring. Affecting almost every
student, the threats were a major disruption to campus life. Third is the continuing development (and
delays) of WJHU, the University's radio station. The
controversy over Hopkins' attempted takeover of
Wyman Park last fall is fourth. Although a compromise was eventually struck allowing the University to use part of the park, Hopkins was at odds with
community leaders for some time. Fifth on the list is
the $209 million bond issue Hopkins financed last fall,
while sixth is the report released in September on the
status of women at Hopkins. The inaugural Fall Break
(both its implementation and its subsequent disappointment) is seventh; eighth is the visit of South
African Anglican Bishop Desmond Tutu in January.
Rounding out the list are the $800 tuition increase announced recently and the irregularities in the meal plan
contract exposed last fall.
In more detail, here is the complete list:

South Africa
Undoubtedly, no issue has received as
much attention this
year as the University's
investments in companies operating in South
Africa. Almost from
the first day of classes,
the matter has been
heavily discussed by
students, faculty members and administrators. Along the way, an almost unprecedented level
of student activity developed: protests were staged at
a Board of Trustees meeting, a boycott of classes was
organized and shanties and gulags were erected on
campus.
In the past, there have admittedly been some students
involved in political protests. Last year, for example,
a few students demonstrated weekly in front of the
South African embassy in Washington. And there have
traditionally been
protests over the
University's nuclear
weapons research.
But in general, the
University has never
been known as a
school with a politically active student
body. It is not, obviously, an Eastern
Berkeley. This year,
however, almost everyone seemed to get animated—
positively or negatively—about South African
divestment.
The issue came to the fore as early as late September,
when the Student Council voted to endorse a class
boycott organized by the Black Student Union. The
event, held on October II, was part of a national protest called "Free Prisoners of Apartheid Day." It
didn't specifically focus on investments in South
Africa, but there was still some discussion of the

A month later, South Africa was back in the news
as Hopkins graduate student Patrick Bond (later a major figure in the pro-divestment movement) orchestrated a campaign to convince Hopkins to assist
Patrick Naidoo, a South African medical student and
political refugee. Once again, the specific issue was not
the University's investments, although the matter continued to be on everyone's mind.
In January, as Hopkins prepared to welcome South
African Anglican Bishop Desmond Tutu, faculty
members, staff members and student groups—most
prominently the Graduate Representative Organization
and the Black Student Union—organized the Hopkins
Coalition for a Free South Africa. The group was
formed to push the University to divest itself of all
stocks of corporations which do business in South
Africa. It argues that such American companies help
support apartheid (the system of racial separation in
South Africa), and that therefore it is immoral for the
University to hold such stocks. The Coalition's first
action was to protest at the Tutu speech.
As the spring wore on the Coalition grew, eventually
organizing a protest at a Board of Trustees meeting
on Feb. 21, a sit-in in Garland Hall on April 4 and
the building of a shanty on the lower quad. The shanty was built, according to Paul Genest, co-coordinator
of the Coalition, to "symbolize the living conditions
of blacks in South Africa."
But as the Coalition grew, so did opposition to it.
The group's first setback came in February, when it
urged the Student Council to sign its "Points of Unity," which advocated divestment. The council voted
10-9 against signing. (Although the vote was widely
interpreted at the time as being a vote on divestment,
some council members said later they objected to the
points themselves, not divestment per se, and on April
9 the council voted 19-1 in favor of divestment.) The
council also decided to hold a referendum of the student body. In a fairly large turn-out, 56 percent of
those voting favored divestment.
About the same time, anti-divestment forces in the
student body began to emerge, as a new group—
Students for lnkatha—appeared, and the College
Republicans publicly argued against divestment. Both
groups claimed divestment would actually hurt the
blacks of South Africa most. Anti-divestment pamphlets went up around campus, and when the Coalition built its shanty the Republicans answered by constructing a gulag, which they said symbolized what
would happen to South Africa if the African National
Congress (which the Coalition supports) takes control
of South Africa. Last Sunday, the two sides met for
the first time in a public debate.
The administration's response to all this has been
mixed. Days before Tutu spoke, the University announced that the Board of Trustees had decided to sell
all stocks of corporations which operate in South
Africa but are not signatories of the Sullivan Principles, a voluntary code of business practices. Since

Bomb Scare
A rash of bomb
threats to the M.S.E.
Library interrupted
and threatened to paralyse the research efforts of many of the
University's students
and faculty for a three
week period earlier this
semester.
In all, nine different
threats from an as yet
unapprehended caller or callers resulted in a series of
library evacuations from February 16 to March 9, according to Manager of Campus Security Robert
Larkin.
Larkin recently told the News-Letter that the investigation is no longer "ongoing," but that the case
is still open.
The rash of threats began on Sunday, February 16
when a caller whose voice was described as that of a
male in his twenties allegedly told an employee at the
library that he hated that establishment and that he
had planted a bomb on A-level, according to Larkin.
The building was
immediately evacuated and searched
by both Homewood
Security and the
Baltimore City Police, but nothing
was found, and the
library later reopened that night
without incident,
according to security.
The following
evening, the same scenario ensued. This time, the
library received two threats and remained closed for
the rest of the evening, although no bomb was ever
found on the premises.
Larkin said at the time that at least one of the calls
was made to a phone that is listed only in the University directory and that the calls apparently came from
somewhere on the campus.
On February 22, the library received yet another
threat forcing the evacuation of M.S.E. once again.
Zan Baughan, building manager of the library, said
at the time that three of the four recently received calls
were made to the same telephone. Larkin eleborated
earlier security suspicions saying that Campus Security believed then that the calls were problably made
from on-campus, possibly even from inside the library
itself.
According to Larkin, the library employee who
answered the phone described the caller as alledgedly
having a "strange scratchy male voice."
At the time of the February 22 threat, Library
Building Superintendant Henry Heath said that library

WJHU
If there were an
award for the most
dichotomous story of
the year, the trials and
tribulations of WJHU
would surely win it.
Throughout the
year, plans have been
made, staff members
have been hired and
studios have been constructed. But with every new accomplishment there seemed to come a new
setback: another delay of the date for the station's
much discussed power increase.
Early last fall, the station was scheduled to go on
the air by March 17, when its extension from the
Federal Communications Commission expired. In
January, however, General Manager David Creagh announced that deadline would not be
met, and predicted
a new start-up date
of early June.
Such delays were
hardly new to
WJHU. Since the
FCC ruled several
years ago that no
stations under 100
watts would be allowed to operate,
the station—currently a 10 watt, student-run operation—has been
planning for a power boost, only to be plagued by
many delays. Last summer, the University finally made
a definitive decision to go ahead with the power in-

crease. Although many students had hoped the larger
station would also be student-run, the administration
quickly announced it would hire professional staff
members for the station. David Creagh, previously the
general manager of KLON-FM in Long Beach,
California, was then hired as the station's general
manager.
Creagh immediately announced that only three positions would be set aside specifically for students, angering many workers at the 10-watt station who felt more
opportunities for students should be available. "I will
not operate on double standards," Creagh said. "Positions are available to students on a competitive basis."
In the fall, work really got underway on the larger
siation, as a managerial team was slowly assembled,
an office building was leased and construction was
begun on studios and a transmitter location was
chosen. In January, however, the station seemed to
suffer two reversals: the delay until June was announced, and Creagh revealed the station would not broadcast at 25,000 watts (the figure traditionally discussed), but at 10,000. This was because the antenna will
be higher than had been previously thought, allowing
the lower wattage to reach the same size audience.
About the same time, a few students currently involved with the 10-watt station proposed the idea of
a second Hopkins radio station. Once the
professionally-managed WJHU goes on the air, they
argued, a smaller, student-run station could be allowed to operate. Two principle alternatives were proposed: a normal broadcast station, or a "carrier station,"
which operates much like a closed-circuit TV station.
In late January, University President Steven Muller
asked Dean of Administration Robert Welch to examine the idea of a second station; Welch has not yet
reported.
A few weeks later, the Student Council decided to
take its own look at the problem, and formed an Ad
Hoc Radio Committee. This week, it is distributing
a survey among students to determine if there is significant interest in a second station.

Wyman Park
While Hopkins has
never been known for
having a completely
affectionate relationship vis-a-vis the surrounding community,
the situation became
far worse last summer
and fall, as the University tried to expand
into nearby Wyman
Park. Fierce opposition arose in the community, but in October a compromise was struck that seemed to please both sides.
The whole affair began during the summer of 1985,
when University officials submitted a plan to the
Baltimore Parks Board to retake 40 acres of the park,
which is adjacent to the campus. The land had
originally been owned by the University, but had been
given to the city between 1902 and 1926.
Hopkins hoped
to construct several
buildings on the
site, including one
for an outside research organization
which would engage
in joint ventures
with the University.
Opposition to the
plan arose quickly,
culminating in Wyman Park Appreciation Day on
Sept. 29. Community members argued the expansion
would displace the park's wildlife, increase traffic in
the area and change the water level, possibly causing
future flooding.
"I just don't want to see it developed," stated City
Councilman Anthony Ambridge, who represents the
area. "It's just a beautiful, beautiful park."
In response to all this, Mayor William Donald
Schaefer—who had apparently originally encouraged
the University to expand into the park—appointed a
task force to study the problem. The panel, composed of community leaders and University representatives, reported to the Mayor in late October.
It recommended that a section of the park be leas-

ed to Hopkins to be used as an intramural athletic
field, thereby allowing the University to build on its
current intramural field, which abuts the park. Task
Force Chairman David Cordish, a Baltimore lawyer,
said this would preserve the park, since an athletic field
would be far less disruptive than new buildings. The
plan won instant approval from both camps and the
Mayor.

Bond Issue
In what has been
called the largest program of its kind in the
histor..y of Hopkins
and of the state, the
University succeeded
last semester in obtaining the necessary financing for a massive
$209 million construction and rennovation
project for Homewood
and the University at large.
The program which will soon change the face of the
University will include, among other projects, the construction of three new research buildings for physics
and astronomy, geo-physics, and neuroscience; rennovations of Gilman, Remsen, and Ames; additions
I to Shaffer and the School of Hygiene and Public
Health; unspecified improvements in student housing;
and the acquisition of a new building in Washington
for the School of Advanced International Studies.
The decision last semester to go ahead with one
massive burst of construction was made primarily to
beat expected federal legislation in
early 1986 that
would have eliminated the tax exempt status for such
project financing.
As University
President Steven
Muller said last fall,
"A major tax law
revision at this time
would represent a
major risk in our
ability to [complete our long term building and renovation goals]."
Muller also remarked that the decision was partially based on a desire to continue attracting "red hot
academic research" in the form of projects similar to
the Space Telescope Science Institute, like the newly
planned neuroscience and geo-physics buildings.
Most of the projects are slaked for ground breaking
from mid-1986 to 1987 with completion dates for all
eighteen major projects scheduled before the end of
the decade, according to Thomas McCracken, director of plant planning.
The multi-million dollar package was financed by
$181 million in revenue bonds from the Maryland
Health and Higher Education Facilities Authority. The
remaining $28 million for the project will come from
the interest on the $181 principle.

B.
David
Anatomist
pretty
Ph.D.,
is
Weishampel,
sure he knows how certain
rhinoceros-size dinosaurs attracted each other's attention
when they plodded around
what's now Alberta, Canada,
72 million years ago.
They honked.
Using PVC tubing from a
hardware store, Weishampel,
assistant professor of cell
biology at the Johns Hopkins
School of Medicine has made a
the
model
life-size
Parasaurolophus' enormous
nasal cavity, found inside a
four-foot-long crest on the reptile's head.
When he blows into the tubing, the sound resonates at
about 48 hertz, a couple of octaves below middle C. The frequency of the low-pitched blast
undoubtedly could be heard IV,
another Parasaurolophus, if the
inner ear of this two-ton reptile
functioned at such a level, as is
widely believed, Weishampel
says.
People tend to giggle when
the scientist hefts his handmade

honker (painted green and firehydrant orange, colors that
modern reptiles—and perhaps
hadrosaurs
like
Parasaurolophus—could see)
and demonstrates its tonal
qualities.
Weishampel
understands the reaction.
"It's big," he says, pulling
the model from its storage box
the way a musician would pick
up a tuba. "People don't
believe this is the actual size."
For a while some scientists
thought the hollow crest was
simply ornamental—a visual
cue the dinosaurs used to
recognize each other. But, while
no one knows if the
Parasaurolophus actually had
vocal cords, a virtually complete skeleton of the beast,
recovered 65 years ago in
Alberta, has not eliminated the
possibility that it vocalized.
Scientists found an ossified
hyoid, the U-shaped cartilage at
the root of the tongue, which
normally is attached to the upper portion of the larynx.
"The fact that this animal
has that bone in place," says

Weishampel, "means that we
know where the vocal organ
would be—if it were there."
Curators at the Royal Ontario Museum, which acquired
the
skeleton,
allowed
Weishampel to cut through
several breaks in the slightly
damaged crest so he could see
inside; that's how he determined
the approximate diameter of
the tubing to use for his model.
The hollow, he found, is "really kind of oblong, not a true
circle, probably so the crest
could support itself." Hardware tubing doesn't come in
that shape, but Weishampel
calculated that the difference
would not affect the tone of the
sound resonating through it
anyway.
Weishampel worked all this
out 10 years ago for his
master's thesis—and, in fact,
he'd be quite willing to bury the
honker in his backyard if it
would give him more time for
his current research on the
evolution of herbivory, from
dinosaurs to modern reptiles
and mammals.

from Paul Basile and fires in a
long one that takes about 1
microsecond to go from stick to
back of net. At 8:18, Bubier
resurfaces, hitting a fallaway
shot from the left side. Navy
wins the faceoff though, and
gets a fastbreak. Just 12
seconds later, Hanzsche scores
from Basile to pull within
11-10. Joe Rzempoluch takes

the ensuing faceoff, gets the
ball to Dressel, and then the cocaptain blows by his man and
fires in. Navy then wins the
next draw, but the clock
doesn't move. Bellestri scores
from Miles twenty seconds
after Dressel's goal, but only 1
second has ticked off the game
clock. The refs confer, and
readjust it to show 5:56 remaining, and Navy down just one
again, 12-11. Exactly one
minute later, it's Bubier again,
and then, finally, the Middies
don't bounce back.

Zimmerman put his team into
an effective stall and killed any
last chance of a comeback.
With just 19 seconds to go,
Bubier fired in his final salvo of
the day to make it a 14-11 final.

Attorney Kurt Schmoke Gives
Graduation Speech for Tutees
by Kris Ann Cappelluti

Ganesh Ramachandran

Kurt Sdimoke, Baltimore City State's Attorney, who presided at the graduation ceremonies of the JHU Tutorial Project.

The Johns Hopkins Tutorial
Program held a graduation
ceremony for both its tutors
and tutees. Baltimore City
State's Attorney Kurt Schmoke
gave the address at the April 29
ceremony.
The program began at approximately 5 p.m. in Shriver
Hall. Gretchen van Utt, the
JHU Chaplain, welcomed the
sizable audience and explained
that although the tutorial program has been a program of the
Chaplain's Office for thirty
years, this was the first time a
formal ceremony had taken
place.
Before welcoming Schmoke,
Liz van Amerongen, who has
been directing the program for
three years, looked over the
past year, reflecting on the two
field trips taken, and the first

essay contest, sponsored by
Delta Sigma Theta sorority.
Van Amerongen was herself a
tutor during her student days at
Loyola. Before Schmoke began
speaking, she presented him
with a turorial program T-shirt
as a token of the group's appreciation of his presence.
Citing his son's belief that "a
politician should only be allowed to speak no longer than a
McDonald's commercial,"
Schmoke gave a brief address.
He congratulated the graduates,
and applauded them for giving
up afternoons to study. He told
the assembly he knew the "importance of education and the
high cost of ignorance."
Schmoke told the group that
the common demoninator that
most young criminals seem to
have is a high rate of truancy.
He also congratulated Hopkins
itself saying,"You can be proud

of what you're [the tutors]
doing, and of what Hopkins is
doing."
Schmoke and van Amerongen
then distributed diplomas to the
89 graduates and their tutors.
Attendance awards were also
distributed.
The students then went on to
present a talent show, after
which refreshments were served in the Clipper Room.
The tutorial program, whose
motto is "there are no failures
here", is divided into two
groups. The Monday-Wednesday group, consisting of 43
students, runs out of East
Baltimore. The Tuesday-Thursday group of 46 students works
out of West Baltimore. Hopkins
students devote several afternoons to helping children improve their math and reading
skills.

To the Editor:
The party I hosted for my
Atomic Cinema students last
semester was funded by myself
with help from a facultystudent interaction program
which was established to sponsor such events. I did not use

indicated in Sujata Banerjee's
article. Both the party and the
infamous dance concert were

viewing of fifteen films about
the end of the world.
I hope I am allowed to continue teaching here and to
dispel the myth that my courses
are all fun and games.
Richard Chisolm

Sono Death
To the Editor:
At 1:00 a.m., April 6, 1986,
eight men, armed with machine
guns broke into home of
Hellets Sono in the township of
Makotopong, South Africa.
Sono, 73, died in the hail of
bullets. His wife Rosalind, 70,
sustained serious head wounds
and their teenage niece, Maria
Mulueke, was brutally raped.
Their daughter, Olive
Shisana, received an Se.D.
from the J HU School of
Hygiene and Public Health in
1984. As a political exile she
could not return home for her
father's funeral, or care for her
injured mother.
Little is known of the attackers, except that at least one
of them was affiliated with the
South African Defense Force.
They were most likely members
of one of the numerous death
squads sponsored by the South
African government.
The attack on the Sono family is but a drop in a bucket of
blood. However, the brutal
murder of Sono has profoundly affected the Hopkins community, and has been especial-

ly disturbing for those of us
who know his daughter personally.
JHU's continued investment
in South Africa perpetuates a
system that rapes and murders
the families of its own students.
It is Shisana's hope that her
friends and colleagues will support her in demanding the complete and immediate divestment
of JHU funds from South
Africa.
Lawrence H. Moulton

Barnstormers Get Ambitious with Shake's Dream
by Peter Oehlkers
Shakespeare, huh. Subtitle
this one "The Barnstormers
Get Ambitious." Hopkins
hasn't put on a Shakespeare
play in this writer's Hopkins
lifetime. Yet odds are, this one
is going to work and turn into
one of the better productions
this school has seen in a while.
Midsummer-night's
A
Dream is hardly the most
serious play in the Shakespeare
book, spending a good deal of
time in fairy-land, but it is a
play of some magnitude and
still requires a fair amount of
talent to pull off. The Barnstormers have been blessed this
time around with a very serious
theatre student, Carol Gerry,
who is taking the directing
mils. Gerry, a recent transfer,
eventually wants to build a
career out of directing the Bard
so I guess that makes her role
here rather appropriaste (you
may want to ask her herself
what she's doing at Hopkins of
all places, that's another story).
In other words, this looks to be
a serious effort.
For those of you who aren't
English majors: the play
revolves around, while never
really focusing on, the marriage

Midsummer-night's Dream this weekend at 8 p.m. in the L/V Room. $2 advance, $3 at the door.

of the heroic Duke of Athens,
Theseus, (played by erstwhile
Arts writer Jason Hanson)and
Hippolyta, queen of the
Amazons. The bulk of the play,
however, deals with a whole
bunch of sets of lovers and
some fairy mischief. Hermia
(Joanne Howell) is being forced to marry Demetrius (Louis
Klieman) but she really loves
Lysander (Scott McNamee),

and Helena (Kathy Kennedy)
really loves Demetrius, though
he could care less. Somehow
they all find their way into the
fairy woods (the fairies have
apparently come from India for
the big wedding) and some
great complications ensue, a
product of the little hobgoblin,
Puck (Kelli Midgley), and some
magic love juice. You see, Puck
is the servant of the fairy-king,

Oberon (Rich Bigelow), who is
having a spat with his wife
Titania (Chrissie Stanfel). He
wants the love juice in order to
embarass her by making her fall
in love with some monstrosity—
which turns out to be an assheaded (literally) local weaver
named Bottom (Greg Harmon).
Etcetera. . .
Gerry hints that the scenes
with the fairies should be

especially flashy, even though
the play itself will be staged
somewhat minimally due to the
constraints of the L/V stage
(and an SAC budget, I assume).
Nevertheless, the forest scenes
will be fascinating due to a
deceptively simple yet effective
stage design. You'll see what I
mean. Furthermore, although
Gerry is quick to point out that
A Midsummer-night's Dream is
essentially a fun, light play, she
feels that this production will
bring out some of the darker
elements in the play as well.
If this production is a success, and the signs point toward
that, perhaps the future of the
Barnstormers lies in a more
serious direction. Let's face it,
even though Godspell ultimately was a pretty good show, any
group of pre-teens anywhere
could put on a convincing performance of that musical. One
of the encouraging signs is the
large crop of freshmen in the
cast of the show—about 60 percent of a cast of 22(!). In
another two or three years the
Barnstormers could be turning
'Baltimore on its ear. That's
could; let's just hope Orgo and
Mole Cell don't claim their
usual victims.

Prince's Bellybutton Hotter Than Ever!
by Sue Trowbridge
I was going to review the new
Prince album this week, but
since half the publications in
America have already done so,
let's turn our attention to some
records that are a bit off the
beaten track. Suffice it to say
that the niftiest things about
Parade are (1) "Girls and
Boys" is one hot dance tune
and (2) Priwe's belly button is
placed exactly on the spine of
the LP's sleeve, so you can see
it even when you file the record
away in your collection. That
makes Prince's navel the most
conspicuous one in America,
even more so than Madonna's.
Jesus Couldn't Drum
Er...Something About Cows
Lost Moment import
There are not many records
where the sleeve notes prove to
be nearly as entertaining as the
music itself. That, however, is
the case with "Er.. .Something
About Cows," the debut album
from a pair of wacky Brits who
call themselves Jesus Couldn't
Drum. Among the 17 songs on
the LP are:
"Tedium of Lettuce"—
"Have you ever noticed how
leafing lettuce can be s0000
boring?"
"This Is Fun"—"An attempt to write the shortest song
ever, and so insure (sic) our inclusion in the next Guiness
Book of Records."
"A Minutes Silence"—"A
pressing fault."
JCD members Peter and
Jonathan each claim a side of

the album. Peter produced five
jittery pop songs with Lester
Square, late of the sadly
departed Monochrome Set. Jon
contributed a sideful of synthesizer wizardry, resulting in
funny little song-fragments like
"The Untimely Demise of Zog
the Duck" and "Wooden
Chicken," as well as some
bright tunes like "Talking To
the Birds." The sides are very
different but both are enjoyable, eccentric, and quite
delightful.

We've Got A Fuzzbox and
We're Gonna Use It
XX Sex
Vindaloo import
It's the band name of the
decade! The record is pressed
on fire engine red vinyl! Who
could ask for more? Great

here, too. In other words,"XX

Sheriff Jack
Let's Be Nonchalant
Midnight Music import
The blindingly bright red and
green cover of "Let's Be Nonchalant," featuring drawings of
odd .little alien creature, gives
few clues as to what the vinyl
inside might sound like. Put the
needle down, though, and the
loopy musings of Robyn Hitchcock come to mind. Like Hitch-

cock, the Sheriff is a great pop
artiste, and his first record is
brimming with potential.
What's more, this four-song
EP was a real Do-It-Yourself
job—he played all the
instruments.
The Beatlesque "We're Gonna Be In Love" is a highlight,
featuring an infectious chorus
and the Sheriff's adept guitar
strumming. On "Buttered Slice
of Democracy," he turns his
madcap eye towards politics.
Best of all, there should be a
full-length album of the
Sheriff's songs coming out
scion. Anonymous though he
may be, there's nothing faceless
about this music.

"Love is What You Have Left to Betray"
A Perfect Spy
by John LeCarre
Alfred A. Knopf, $18.95. 475
pages.
by Cliff Robinson
In A Perfect Spy, John
LeCarre has brought his
readers a complicated, very
emotional story of betrayal and
searches on several levels.
Moreover, A Perfect Spy tells
of Magnus Pym, senior British
Intelligence operative, who
disappears after the death of his
father. Taking a lifetime of
secrets with him, Pym embarks
on a journey through his own
life's story, trying to find his
true "self"—a part of him that
is genuine, and not just a cover
for one of his numerous
betrayals.
LeCarre's main characters
always seem to be tormented,
and are usually involved in
some kind of search for their
own identity. Like the heroine
in The Little Drummer Girl, or
George Smiley in Smiley's People, the lives of LeCarre's
characters are somehow in-

complete, and they look for
something to fill the gap.
Usually, however, that search is
secondary to the main action of
the novel. In A Perfect Spy,
Magnus Pym's search for
himself is the primary focus of
the plot. The main aspect of the
book, the development of
Magnus Pym's character, is
especially well done. Pym is
revealed as a man with no close
personal involvements, no
discernable loyalty to anyone.
He also has no true character,
no driving focus or goals—he
does not know who he is, and
neither does anyone else. While
this may make him a "perfect
spy," it also makes him a deeply troubled man, one in search
of a mission, a cause, or an
identity.
When we are first introduced
to Magnus, we see a man who
is warm, effusive, well-liked by
everyone he knows and loved
by many. He is able to be many
things to many people, and virtually everyone has a slightly
different impression of him.
Yet while many love Magnus,
no one is truly close to him. His
wife and he seem to have a

beautiful relationship, which
everyone admires, but she
doesn't share his secrets. Nor
do his agents or colleagues in
British Intelligence really
understand him.
This ability to change
"masks" so readily makes him
an ideal spy, but behind Pym's
masks, there is nothing. We
soon realize, as does Magnus,
that his entire being is devoted
to the expression of countless
superficial identities—he cannot find a private self apart
from his facades.
skillfully
LeCarre
demonstrates this as Magnus
writes to his son Tom, telling
him about his life. Almost exclusively, Magnus refers to
himself as Pym, especially
when he is acting in an assumed
identity, even with his family.
The only time he says "I" is if
he speaks of a deeply meaningful, important event, and
then only with great emotion.
The fact that "I" appears so infrequently shows that any part
of him which feels deeply, or
truly cares about anything, is
very small and hidden amid the
masks of faces which make up

his "covers." There is little left
of the true Magnus Pym. As
another agent says to him,
"Magnus, you are the perfect
spy. Now all you need is a
mission."
It is the search for this mission that causes Magnus to
disappear, and begin a journey
through his past. "Sometimes
our actions are questions, not
answers," he says, and calls his
disappearance "The first conscious decision I ever made in
my life." As he unravels the
threads of his life, his
childhood is shown to be a
training ground for a lifetime of
betrayals, hidden meanings and
intrigue. At the same time,
British Intelligence is looking
for him, and trying to understand him and his motives.
Gradually, they both begin to
realize that for his whole life,
his lack of conscious decisions
is a result of his not having a
cause to be loyal to, a single
person to care about, or any
driving force behind his actions. He becomes enmeshed in
a circle of duplicity, with double agents whose loyalty is constantly in question. His rela-

tionship with his wife parallels
his career, and his loyalty to his
country, and again he is unwilling, or unable, to make a strong
commitment.
To a large extent, Pym's
search goes unresolved. Even at
the end of the book, questions
still remain about the ultimate
motives of both Pym and some
of the agents he is involved
with. We are not sure if he intended to betray those things he
thought were important for
some greater cause. He may
love his country, his father, his
son. Or he may still have no
loyalty, not even to himself. It
seems that he himself is unsure,
as if LeCarre wishes to avoid
making any statement about
the final value of commitments.
Instead, we just see that all
Pym's relationships are based
upon deceit. Pym says, "Love
is what you have left to
betray," so it may very well be
that he loves most what he
betrays. It does not matter
ultimately, for when all the interpretations are stripped away,
A Perfect Spy is still an excellent spy novel, and wellrecommended.

To the Editor:
, Lately, the Coalition for a
Free South Africa has indulged
its confrontational streak and
delighted greatly in hurling the
epithet "stooge" in the direction of Mangosuthu Buthelezi,
leader of the Inkatha movement. This not only goes far in
darkening and trivializing the
open debate on campus about
divestment, but is belies many
facts that are crucial to all those
groups who are seeking change

in South Africa by invovling
themselves in this debate.
Mangosuthu Buthelezi, a
devout Anglican, follows a
principle of political action that
should be well-known to all
Americans. This is the tenet of
nonviolent action as a means of
controlled change and freedom
and justice for all peoples. This
is no claim that Buthelezi
created this philosophy; it is
well known that two figures in
world history no less than
Mahatma Gandhi and Martin
Luther King, Jr. were pioneers
in this system of ideals.
However, do we label the firs a
"stooge" of the British colonial
government in India or of
Viceroy Mountbatten? Do we
call King a "pawn" or
"stooge" of John F. Kennedy
simply because he was against
bloodshed? The answer is a
simple "no." Both men are
revered as great heroes and only labeled as villains by those
who do not understand that
violence is idiocy.
The Coalition often asks how
long the peoples of nonviolence
wish to wait to end apartheid.
50 years? 100 years? However,
an equally relevant question is
how many lives do the supporters of murder and guerrilla
warfare wish to take to end
apartheid? 100,000 dead?
300,000 dead? These are not
unrealistic figures if total civil
war erupts in South Africa.
People such as the ANC's
Oliver, Bishop Tutu and the
Coalition for a Free South
Africa (by virtue of their
devoted support of the ANC)
all seem to advocate violence.
As Tambo has said,"We wish
to make this country ungovernable." Buthelezi and Inkatha
can only denounce this violence
and fight off the rain of epithets
of hatred thrown toward them.
In the words of Buthelezi, "I
realize that there are many peo'pie who hate my guts for daring even to grope for a peaceful
solution after the violence that
has been unleashed against
blacks in the past months. I am
not ashamed to do whatever is
within the realm of the possible
to prevent bloodshed." It is for
this reason that Buthelezi is
against divestment and works
to preserve peace and stability
in South Africa, as well as to
end apartheid.
William Wallace
The writer is a member of
Students for Inkatha.

The Year in Review: The Ten B
It has been, in many ways, an unusual academic year
for Hopkins. At a school known for having a politically apathetic student body, protests and sit-ins became
almost commonplace. At a school with a relatively
small campus, the administration announced it would
spend more than $200 million to expand in the next
few years alone. At perhaps the nation's leading premed factory, the MCAT (the standard medical school
admissions test) became optional.
In other ways, though, it has been an utterly typical
year. Tuition was increased almost $1000, the Student
Council feuded with the Student Activities Commission and WJHU suffered more delays on the road to
its much-discussed power boost.
As a way of looking back at 1985-86, the Editor and
News Editors of the News-Letter chose the year's 10
biggest news events. All of them effected students,
faculty members and administrators; some of them
changed (or will change) the nature of Hopkins.
First on the list is the continuing controversy
throughout the year about the University's investments
in corporations which do business in South Africa.
Quite Simply, no other story even came close to capturing as much attention as this one. Second are the
plague of bomb threats which struck the Milton S.
Eisenhower Library this spring. Affecting almost every
student, the threats were a major disruption to campus life. Third is the continuing development (and
delays) of WJHU, the University's radio station. The
controversy over Hopkins' attempted takeover of
Wyman Park last fall is fourth. Although a compromise was eventually struck allowing the University to use part of the park, Hopkins was at odds with
community leaders for some time. Fifth on the list is
the $209 million bond issue Hopkins financed last fall,
while sixth is the report released in September on the
status of women at Hopkins. The inaugural Fall Break
(both its implementation and its subsequent disappointment) is seventh; eighth is the visit of South
African Anglican Bishop Desmond Tutu in January.
Rounding out the list are the $800 tuition increase announced recently and the irregularities in the meal plan
contract exposed last fall.
In more detail, here is the complete list:

South Africa
Undoubtedly, no issue has received as
much attention this
year as the University's
investments in companies operating in South
Africa. Almost from
the first day of classes,
the matter has been
heavily discussed by
students, faculty members and administrators. Along the way, an almost unprecedented level
of student activity developed: protests were staged at
a Board of Trustees meeting, a boycott of classes was
organized and shanties and gulags were erected on
campus.
In the past, there have admittedly been some students
involved in political protests. Last year, for example,
a few students demonstrated weekly in front of the
South African embassy in Washington. And there have
traditionally been
protests over the
University's nuclear
weapons research.
But in general, the
University has never
been known as a
school with a politically active student
body. It is not, obviously, an Eastern
Berkeley. This year,
however, almost everyone seemed to get animated—
positively or negatively—about South African
divestment.
The issue came to the fore as early as late September,
when the Student Council voted to endorse a class
boycott organized by the Black Student Union. The
event, held on October II, was part of a national protest called "Free Prisoners of Apartheid Day." It
didn't specifically focus on investments in South
Africa, but there was still some discussion of the

A month later, South Africa was back in the news
as Hopkins graduate student Patrick Bond (later a major figure in the pro-divestment movement) orchestrated a campaign to convince Hopkins to assist
Patrick Naidoo, a South African medical student and
political refugee. Once again, the specific issue was not
the University's investments, although the matter continued to be on everyone's mind.
In January, as Hopkins prepared to welcome South
African Anglican Bishop Desmond Tutu, faculty
members, staff members and student groups—most
prominently the Graduate Representative Organization
and the Black Student Union—organized the Hopkins
Coalition for a Free South Africa. The group was
formed to push the University to divest itself of all
stocks of corporations which do business in South
Africa. It argues that such American companies help
support apartheid (the system of racial separation in
South Africa), and that therefore it is immoral for the
University to hold such stocks. The Coalition's first
action was to protest at the Tutu speech.
As the spring wore on the Coalition grew, eventually
organizing a protest at a Board of Trustees meeting
on Feb. 21, a sit-in in Garland Hall on April 4 and
the building of a shanty on the lower quad. The shanty was built, according to Paul Genest, co-coordinator
of the Coalition, to "symbolize the living conditions
of blacks in South Africa."
But as the Coalition grew, so did opposition to it.
The group's first setback came in February, when it
urged the Student Council to sign its "Points of Unity," which advocated divestment. The council voted
10-9 against signing. (Although the vote was widely
interpreted at the time as being a vote on divestment,
some council members said later they objected to the
points themselves, not divestment per se, and on April
9 the council voted 19-1 in favor of divestment.) The
council also decided to hold a referendum of the student body. In a fairly large turn-out, 56 percent of
those voting favored divestment.
About the same time, anti-divestment forces in the
student body began to emerge, as a new group—
Students for lnkatha—appeared, and the College
Republicans publicly argued against divestment. Both
groups claimed divestment would actually hurt the
blacks of South Africa most. Anti-divestment pamphlets went up around campus, and when the Coalition built its shanty the Republicans answered by constructing a gulag, which they said symbolized what
would happen to South Africa if the African National
Congress (which the Coalition supports) takes control
of South Africa. Last Sunday, the two sides met for
the first time in a public debate.
The administration's response to all this has been
mixed. Days before Tutu spoke, the University announced that the Board of Trustees had decided to sell
all stocks of corporations which operate in South
Africa but are not signatories of the Sullivan Principles, a voluntary code of business practices. Since

If there were an
award for the most
dichotomous story of
the year, the trials and
tribulations of WJHU
would surely win it.
Throughout the
year, plans have been
made, staff members
have been hired and
studios have been constructed. But with every new accomplishment there seemed to come a new
setback: another delay of the date for the station's
much discussed power increase.
Early last fall, the station was scheduled to go on
the air by March 17, when its extension from the
Federal Communications Commission expired. In
January, however, General Manager David Creagh announced that deadline would not be
met, and predicted
a new start-up date

Such delays were

WJHU. Since the

years ago that no
stations under 100
watts would be allowed to operate,
the station—currently a 10 watt, student-run operation—has been
planning for a power boost, only to be plagued by
many delays. Last summer, the University finally made
a definitive decision to go ahead with the power in-

crease. Although many students had hoped the larger

manager.

not operate on double standards," Creagh said. "Positions are available to students on a competitive basis."

an office building was leased and construction was
begun on studios and a transmitter location was
chosen. In January, however, the station seemed to
suffer two reversals: the delay until June was announced, and Creagh revealed the station would not broadcast at 25,000 watts (the figure traditionally discussed), but at 10,000. This was because the antenna will
be higher than had been previously thought, allowing
the lower wattage to reach the same size audience.
About the same time, a few students currently involved with the 10-watt station proposed the idea of
a second Hopkins radio station. Once the
professionally-managed WJHU goes on the air, they
argued, a smaller, student-run station could be allowed to operate. Two principle alternatives were proposed: a normal broadcast station, or a "carrier station,"
which operates much like a closed-circuit TV station.
In late January, University President Steven Muller
asked Dean of Administration Robert Welch to examine the idea of a second station; Welch has not yet
reported.
A few weeks later, the Student Council decided to
take its own look at the problem, and formed an Ad
Hoc Radio Committee. This week, it is distributing
a survey among students to determine if there is significant interest in a second station.

Wyman Park
While Hopkins has
never been known for
having a completely
affectionate relationship vis-a-vis the surrounding community,
the situation became
far worse last summer
and fall, as the University tried to expand
into nearby Wyman
Park. Fierce opposition arose in the community, but in October a compromise was struck that seemed to please both sides.
The whole affair began during the summer of 1985,
when University officials submitted a plan to the
Baltimore Parks Board to retake 40 acres of the park,
which is adjacent to the campus. The land had
originally been owned by the University, but had been
given to the city between 1902 and 1926.
Hopkins hoped
to construct several
buildings on the
site, including one
for an outside research organization
which would engage
in joint ventures
with the University.
Opposition to the
plan arose quickly,
culminating in Wyman Park Appreciation Day on
Sept. 29. Community members argued the expansion
would displace the park's wildlife, increase traffic in
the area and change the water level, possibly causing
future flooding.
"I just don't want to see it developed," stated City
Councilman Anthony Ambridge, who represents the
area. "It's just a beautiful, beautiful park."
In response to all this, Mayor William Donald
Schaefer—who had apparently originally encouraged
the University to expand into the park—appointed a
task force to study the problem. The panel, composed of community leaders and University representatives, reported to the Mayor in late October.
It recommended that a section of the park be leas-

ed to Hopkins to be used as an intramural athletic
field, thereby allowing the University to build on its
current intramural field, which abuts the park. Task
Force Chairman David Cordish, a Baltimore lawyer,
said this would preserve the park, since an athletic field
would be far less disruptive than new buildings. The
plan won instant approval from both camps and the
Mayor.

Bond Issue
In what has been
called the largest program of its kind in the
histor..y of Hopkins
and of the state, the
University succeeded
last semester in obtaining the necessary financing for a massive
$209 million construction and rennovation
project for Homewood
and the University at large.
The program which will soon change the face of the
University will include, among other projects, the construction of three new research buildings for physics
and astronomy, geo-physics, and neuroscience; rennovations of Gilman, Remsen, and Ames; additions
I to Shaffer and the School of Hygiene and Public
Health; unspecified improvements in student housing;
and the acquisition of a new building in Washington
for the School of Advanced International Studies.
The decision last semester to go ahead with one
massive burst of construction was made primarily to
beat expected federal legislation in
early 1986 that
would have eliminated the tax exempt status for such
project financing.
As University
President Steven
Muller said last fall,
"A major tax law
revision at this time
would represent a
major risk in our
ability to [complete our long term building and renovation goals]."
Muller also remarked that the decision was partially based on a desire to continue attracting "red hot
academic research" in the form of projects similar to
the Space Telescope Science Institute, like the newly
planned neuroscience and geo-physics buildings.
Most of the projects are slaked for ground breaking
from mid-1986 to 1987 with completion dates for all
eighteen major projects scheduled before the end of
the decade, according to Thomas McCracken, director of plant planning.
The multi-million dollar package was financed by
$181 million in revenue bonds from the Maryland
Health and Higher Education Facilities Authority. The
remaining $28 million for the project will come from
the interest on the $181 principle.

Meal Plan
Students subscribing
to the ARA meal service have chronically
complained about the
quality of the food,
but last November
many started complaining about the
price.
In an investigative
report first semester,
the News-Letter reported the prices of the various meal plans, comparing them to the cost of buying meals on a daily basis.
It was found that if students were on the 14 meal per
week plan and did not attend intersession, they would
need to eat 106.8 percent of their meals in order to
save money, an obvious impossibility. The NewsLetter also showed that if the fourteen meal subscriber
did attend intercession, he would have to eat 98.4 percent of his meals.
Bettye Miller, director of Auxiliary Enterprises said
at the time that the costs of "casual" meals and the
meal plans could not be compared. Miller added that
"We do not base its [the meal plan's] cost on the casual
meal rate. There is no rationale to it."
Miller also said that the meal plan costs could not
be lowered, saying, "to lower the cost of the meal plan
would be to lower the quality of the food. They would
serve sawdust if they had to."
Although admitting that few people eat in the Terrace Room on a casual basis, Miller added that raising the prices of the casual meals would discourage
the few who did attend on a daily basis.
Further investigation of the meal plan prices revealed an even greater disparity in the differences of price
between the meal plans and the casual rates. It was
found that since the 19 meal plan subscribers ate only
75 percent of their meals they were paying an average
of $3.89 per meal if they attended intercession and
$4.23 if they didn't.

Anatomist

Weishampel,
sure he knows how certain
rhinoceros-size dinosaurs attracted each other's attention
when they plodded around
what's now Alberta, Canada,
72 million years ago.
They honked.
Using PVC tubing from a
hardware store, Weishampel,
assistant professor of cell
biology at the Johns Hopkins
School of Medicine has made a
the
model
life-size
Parasaurolophus' enormous
nasal cavity, found inside a
four-foot-long crest on the reptile's head.
When he blows into the tubing, the sound resonates at
about 48 hertz, a couple of octaves below middle C. The frequency of the low-pitched blast
undoubtedly could be heard IV,
another Parasaurolophus, if the
inner ear of this two-ton reptile
functioned at such a level, as is
widely believed, Weishampel
says.
People tend to giggle when
the scientist hefts his handmade

honker (painted green and firehydrant orange, colors that
modern reptiles—and perhaps
hadrosaurs
like
Parasaurolophus—could see)
and demonstrates its tonal
qualities.
Weishampel
understands the reaction.
"It's big," he says, pulling
the model from its storage box
the way a musician would pick
up a tuba. "People don't
believe this is the actual size."
For a while some scientists
thought the hollow crest was
simply ornamental—a visual
cue the dinosaurs used to
recognize each other. But, while
no one knows if the
Parasaurolophus actually had
vocal cords, a virtually complete skeleton of the beast,
recovered 65 years ago in
Alberta, has not eliminated the
possibility that it vocalized.
Scientists found an ossified
hyoid, the U-shaped cartilage at
the root of the tongue, which
normally is attached to the upper portion of the larynx.
"The fact that this animal
has that bone in place," says

Weishampel, "means that we
know where the vocal organ
would be—if it were there."
Curators at the Royal Ontario Museum, which acquired
the
skeleton,
allowed
Weishampel to cut through
several breaks in the slightly
damaged crest so he could see
inside; that's how he determined
the approximate diameter of
the tubing to use for his model.
The hollow, he found, is "really kind of oblong, not a true
circle, probably so the crest
could support itself." Hardware tubing doesn't come in
that shape, but Weishampel
calculated that the difference
would not affect the tone of the
sound resonating through it
anyway.
Weishampel worked all this
out 10 years ago for his
master's thesis—and, in fact,
he'd be quite willing to bury the
honker in his backyard if it
would give him more time for
his current research on the
evolution of herbivory, from
dinosaurs to modern reptiles
and mammals.
